awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Biodegradable Electronic Sensors to Measure Environmental Data for Perishable Goods
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact / commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to minimize food waste, reduce electronic sensor waste, and develop a printed, biodegradable, electronic sensor. According to the United Nations, food waste is valued at $2.4 trillion/year worldwide with the majority of the expense attributed to transport. Electronic waste is approximately 50 million tons/year with less than 18% being recycled globally. Currently, disposable sensors are used to prevent food waste, yet these sensors contribute to the electronic waste problem. The proposed printed, biodegradable sensors will enhance scientific and technological understanding to move from disposable to on-demand biodegradable sensors. The market opportunity addressed by the proposed technology is over $300 billion in the food supply chain and even larger in the broader perishable markets. The technological shift to printed, biodegradable sensors will provide a competitive advantage compared to other companies that are using disposable or semi-recyclable materials. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project involves the development of carbon-based, printable, electronic materials to produce a biodegradable sensing platform for measuring temperature and humidity. The proliferation of electronic sensors continues to provide access to transformative data, improving health, the environment, and transportation. However, resultant electronic sensor waste is a critical concern that precludes use for certain applications. This project will use graphene for conducting, carbon nanotubes for semiconducting, and crystalline nanocellulose for insulating inks that can be printed into temperature and humidity sensors on a thin film of cellulose (i.e., paper). Technical obstacles include the co-integration of these all-carbon inks, realization of target electrical properties, and yield of functional sensors. The goals of this project include: (1) the formulation of nanomaterial inks for their co-printing onto biodegradable substrates; (2) the development of aerosol jet printing processes; and (3) the demonstration of temperature and humidity sensors from the printed carbon-based nanomaterials. To achieve these goals, innovations in the formulation of these carbon-based inks will be required, along with the design of sensor configurations that yield reliable temperature and humidity measurements. More than a dozen distinct sensor designs will be explored, and iterative tuning of ink and sensor designs will take place.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Transparent Path, in collaboration with Duke University, successfully completed its NSF Phase I STTR project to develop biodegradable, printed IoT sensors for monitoring temperature and humidity. This initiative aimed to address two critical global challenges: reducing food waste and mitigating the environmental impact of electronic waste (e-waste). The project achieved significant milestones that demonstrate the feasibility of creating sustainable IoT devices while maintaining performance comparable to existing commercial technologies.

Intellectual Merit

The project focused on advancing materials science and printed electronics by developing fully printed, all-carbon thin-film transistors (CNT-TFTs) and functional temperature and humidity sensors on biodegradable substrates. Key achievements include:

  • Development of Carbon-Based Inks: The team formulated water-based inks using graphene for conductivity, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) for semiconducting properties, and crystalline nanocellulose (CNC) for insulation. These inks were optimized for compatibility with biodegradable substrates such as paper, cellophane, and materbi.
  • Fabrication of CNT-TFTs: Using aerosol jet printing, the team successfully created multi-layer CNT-TFTs with no intermixing between layers. These devices operated at low voltages and demonstrated excellent electrical performance.
  • Functional Sensors: Graphene-based temperature and humidity sensors were fabricated using a meander line architecture. The sensors were tested in commercially relevant environments, demonstrating high sensitivity, stability, and repeatability.

The results showed that these biodegradable devices could perform comparably to Transparent Path’s existing IoT trackers while significantly reducing their environmental footprint.

Broader Impacts

The project has broader societal implications beyond its technical achievements:

  • Reducing Food Waste: By enabling real-time monitoring of environmental conditions during food transportation, the sensors help reduce spoilage, ensuring more perishable goods reach consumers.
  • Minimizing E-Waste: The use of biodegradable materials in sensor fabrication addresses the growing global challenge of e-waste, promoting sustainable manufacturing practices.
  • Public Awareness: The project highlighted the dual issues of food waste and e-waste, fostering greater awareness among stakeholders about sustainable solutions in logistics.

Key Outcomes

  1. Milestone 1: Successfully developed all-carbon CNT-TFTs on biodegradable substrates by optimizing carbon-based ink formulations and printing processes.
  2. Milestone 2: Fabricated functional temperature and humidity sensors with performance comparable to commercial trackers. These devices were benchmarked against Transparent Path’s existing IoT trackers under controlled conditions.
  3. Sustainability: All printing processes used water-based inks, eliminating harmful solvents and reducing material waste.

The Phase I project demonstrated the potential for integrating biodegradable IoT sensors into supply chains to address food spoilage while minimizing environmental impact. These findings lay the groundwork for future innovations in sustainable IoT technologies.

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2025
Modified by: Sunil Koduri
